newsitem.title: ISRAEL: ISRAEL CPI-LINKED BONDS HIGHER BUT SELLERS APPEAR.
newsitem.headline: ISRAEL CPI-LINKED BONDS HIGHER BUT SELLERS APPEAR.

text.p: Israeli CPI-linked bonds closed higher on Thursday while prices of unlinked bonds fell on expectations of a high July consumer price index (CPI), traders said.
Indices:
* Government bonds general: +0.05 pct to 111.55
* CPI-linked government bonds: +0.13 pct to 112.01
* Unlinked government bonds: -0.17 pct to 109.92
* Dollar-linked government bonds: -0.1 pct to 111.33
* Bank of Israel short-term Makam bills: -0.02 pct to 108.49
Volume including Makams was a high 270 million shekels.
"Prices of unlinked bonds fell considerably because of expectations of a high July CPI of around 1.0-1.1 percent," said Roy Meir of Simodan.
"Traders are afraid interest rates will go up," he said.
Meir said prices of CPI-linked bonds continued to rise on Thursday on the high CPI expectations and on the tight supply of these bonds expected in August.
"Yields of CPI-linked long bonds have fallen to around 3.7 percent," he said.

"Prices of CPI-linked bonds continued higher today but for the first time in a while there were also sellers of CPI-linked bonds and buyers of unlinked bonds, which explains the high volume," said Tiki Haddad of IBI Investment House.

Haddad said that because yields of CPI-linked bonds had fallen significantly in the past few weeks, these bonds had become unattractive and traders had started buying unlinked bonds whose yields have been on the rise.
"There was an enormous amount of sellers of CPI-linked instruments in off-the-floor trading," Haddad said.

Government bond redemptions are expected to total about four billion shekels in August against issues of 1.6 billion shekels; a successful privatisation process and higher tax revenues are all expected to lessen the government's need to raise debt on the bond market.
Traders said that the shortage was expected to affect all government bonds, but especially CPI-linked bonds.

The Treasury said on Wednesday it would issue 1.6 billion shekels worth of bonds in August. Of these issues, 900 million shekels would be in CPI-linked bonds and 700 million shekels in unlinked bonds. The Treasury said it would not issue any dollar-linked bonds in August.
The rise of the dollar against the shekel in June, which caused June's CPI to rise a steep 1.1 percent, has triggered fears of a series of high indices in July and August.
July's CPI will be published on August 15.
Prices of dollar-linked bonds closed stable, traders said.
Note: Makams are zero-coupon unlinked certificates with durations of three months to one year. The Bank of Israel issues Makams to absorb liquidity.
($1 = 3.53 shekels)
